reviewText: Excellent band and music.  But the video editing is horrific - they cut to another camera view every second (or faster in many cases).  This DVD isn't worth a dime - I recommend that you don't buy it.
Title: N/A

reviewText: To the clueless people who say that no one could possibly have a US version of this DVD yet, you are wrong.  They do manufacture and ship the DVDs before the release date, you know, and some stores put them out early.  What I got is NOT the Region 2 version, but a US version which is indeed flawed, and in a different way than the Region 2 PAL versions.  Sorry for that rant....THE GOOD:  The sound is really incredible.  The 5.1 Surround Mix sounds great [EDIT 2/28/06 - apparently I watched the stereo DVD as I have only just now found out the DVDs are mislabeled - so I just wanted to point out that I should have said the stereo mix sounds fantastic - as far as the 5.1, I'll have to listen to it for myself to see if it is as bad as folks on here are saying.  Sadly, I don't doubt it].  I have been a Maiden fan for 20 years and have to say Dance of the Death is a really strong record (it grows with listens).  If you hate DoD this won't be for you - it's heavily represented.  But there is also a good selection of the 'staple' Maiden Classics.  Maiden have truly never sounded better - the band are in top form and Bruce is incredible.  Watch that DVD of his 'last' Maiden gig and compare, he is WAY better today.The documentary was really well done and showed Maiden in the studio writing and recording DoD, as well as preparing for and going on the tour.  It is over an hour, and there are outtakes which are also quite good.  The documentary alone is worth getting this DVD.THE BAD: I cannot stand the recent trend of super fast edit jumping.  Considering the amazing stage show Maiden puts on it would be nice to be able to focus on it for a mere moment, but the video jumps literally every 1 to 2 seconds, with only a FEW (and still far too quick) exceptions.  Also, while it's great to hear the classic Maiden tunes, they have released enough live albums where a little variety would be nice.  There is *some* here (I hate the Blaze era Maiden, but I think 'Lord of the Flies' was a great inclusion here - Bruce breaths some fresh air into the tune), but a lot of it is the same old stuff we've heard live a hundred times before.These DVDs are most likely going to be recalled, and the release date pushed back.  What happens is that when you select the Play All function it works - for a little while.  After a few songs you get kicked into the 'Song Selection' menu.  DO NOT select the next song in this menu or you'll have to do that for EACH song.  Instead go back to the Main Menu and again select Play All, then immediately skip to the song that was next.  It'll work again - at least for awhile.  Unfortunately it happens again, but no more than a total of 2 or 3 times.  Annoying, yes, but I'm still glad I got mine.  If you are forced to wait, rest assured, it will be well worth it.
summary: Defective US DVDs to be recalled :(
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a well produced DVD document of a pretty darn good Iron Maiden show on the Dance Of Death tour. Death On The Road deliberately repeats the various successes (and frankly HALF the song selection) of Rock In Rio released years earlier, and I would not pause one second to buy these concerts & those of IM vocalist Bruce Dickinson.It has to be said the crowd is not nearly as screaming-bonkers the one at the Rio De Janiero show. But it is indeed a happy, adoring crowd of polite North Euros who do get very involved in the singing chants. And Maiden's comeback success - as headliners drawing even very young fans! - well, this is VERY gratifying to see as an early fan myself. The extras & interviews show such a positive time for the band right now, just all smooth sailing and flawless touring.I'm glad the band is so comfortable now, effortlessly drawing new fans. Yet I'm alarmed to learn they write records like DOD largely in the studio just banging ideas out & seeing what they come up with. Dance Of Death not a bad record, and near to BNW in quality, but overall I feel the songwriting COULD be far better & the last two albums could have been done more consistently brilliant. It's largely Steve Harris' vision, sure, that's cool. Maiden may yet have still greater unused potential I think, so to hear how they put records together - well it makes them seem almost blasé about the actual songs rather than passionately creating true classics. Certainly earlier material tunes like 'Wrathchild' & 'Hallowed Be Thy Name' were far more inspired and EACH must have been honed down obsessively from weeks of creative daydreaming. Does a truly epic record not deserve this much imagination and effort?It is interesting to contrast Bruce D (interviewed on the BD Anthology DVD) talking about his own organic, 'self-evolving' approach to writing songs with Roy Z. While he does not directly reference Iron Maiden for contrast (and why would he) the comparison is apt because you hear a difference. I find Bruce's solo material FAR more inspired and developed, perhaps as a direct result of using every potential in the writing process.One very good reason to buy the "Death" DVD is that on "Iron Maiden" you can actually hear the vocals, unlike the Rio concert which had (radio mic?) problems on that song. Of course Maiden now record ALL shows as audio backup, so they can edit between shows - and eventually release MONSTER live CDs of exceptional song performances, in 5.1!)There are pluses to either release - overall I like the energy of RIO and I find Bruce's voice on RIO just shines a little more brightly, and the almost giddy energy of the band is more palpable. Again, half the songs are just repeats found on EITHER DVD, so although RIO is maybe the winner by a neck, both shows are very good, exciting home viewing.Maiden is a band that could (once again?) slide into years of auto-pilot (and I'm not saying they are, they MAY) or they could elevate their work to produce some of the most brilliant hard rock of our decade. It is really up to them, because the crown is theirs to do with as they please.

reviewText: I agree with those who complain about the constant video cuts. Constant. You never get a shot of anything for more than 2 seconds. God, how I hate music videos like this. ACDC Thunderstruck was the same way. I gave that title away after only browsing it for 10 minutes. It sucked. So does this - but it's even worse with the fast cuts.Luckily I didn't purchase "Death on the Road," and I certainly won't be buying it having watched it. Well, actually I didn't watch the whole thing. It began to make me sick and I developed a headache. After making sure the entire thing was the same tripe, I walked away.Concerts ARE NOT like this. The whole object of going to a concert IS TO SEE THE BAND. To watch them perform onstage. Iron Maiden is chock full of top-o-the-line musicians and performers, and they got chopped to bits with the editing. Iron Maiden doesn't need stupid editing. They are the real thing. Just let us watch the show, man. Get out of the way.This is no complaint against Iron Maiden or their music. I've been a fan for 25 years. They should go back and redo this, all the footage is probably still whole. Make a version for those of us not on Dilantin or PhenoBarb.I still love Iron Maiden all the same - just thank God I was able to preview this without having to blow my hard earned cash. I wouldn't keep it even if it was given to me. I certainly wouldn't ever watch it again (not even partially).I own tons of concert DVD's and VHS tapes. Many of them fall into this same retarded trap. Somebody get that fool out of the processing room! Even if it is Steve Harris!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Like a lot of bands, they peak and then spend the remaining years trying to recapture the lost magic.  This is seldom done.  Aerosmith is a great exception to the rule.  I have been a Maiden fan since 1981 and will go see them every time they come to town but let's face it. 2005 Iron Maiden is a very different monster than the Live After Death band from 1985.  Actually no comparison.  DVDs and live albums sell and these guys know it.  That is why there is another one from yet another tour.  Just like the Rolling Stones.  Older maiden fans save your money and buy a CD with a group of good songs, not from a band that is truly functioning and cashing in on former glories.  Just because it says IRON MAIDEN doesn't necessarily mean good things.  The name is a cash cow but that doesn't mean we should reward these guys for mediocre songs and product.  Buy "The Early Years" instead.  You will feel much better and the nostalgia trip will be well worth it.  This leaves one just remembering what Maiden once was.
summary: Buy the CD and DVD if you really like what Maiden has put out in the last decade, otherwise skip this!

reviewText: Theoretically, Steve Harris was the one to take more care than anyone elese when giving birth to his new "baby": the DVD Death On The Road". This show comes in gorgeous packaging, and contains a very interesting bonus DVD.However, when it comes to its main attraction (the show DVD), it's a complete digrace. Bad edition destroyed the live footage, to the point of getting numb while watching it, scratching your eyes trying do adjust to something incredibly bad taste, like it's the case with the edition of this show... Blinding-fast, where you can not watch any single band member, you can't enjoy the show. I just don't get it. Go figure what Harris was thinking...
summary: Death to my eyes on the road

reviewText: This video is truly awesome.  Until the Flight 666 movie, this was the best video Maiden had ever done.  It is well worth the purchase if you like Maiden.  The clarity is super.  The only drawback, in my opinion, is that during truly awesome guitar solos, the clips kept changing as fast as Nicko beat on his drum.  You could never simply stay on Dave or Adrian to watch and enjoy their expertise on the guitar during their solos.  Yeah, okay, Jannick, too, but less so.That about covers it.  I've been a Maiden fan since I first saw them in 1980 when I was stationed in Germany.  I have seen them many times since, including twice on this past world tour (Chicago & Ft. Lauderdale).Up the Irons!!!
summary: Maiden Still Rules After All These Years!!!
Title: N/A

reviewText: The first time I watched this, I turned it off after the opening track. I noticed the same editing flaws that "Rock In Rio" possessed, and therefore I couldn't bare to stomach anymore. I put it back in it's case, back on the shelf, and there it stayed until just the other day....Needless to say, being the long time Maiden fan that I am{1981 - old schooler}, every once in a while I get a Maiden craving that needs fixing. I had bought "Death On The Road", and I knew that I hadn't really given it an honest view when I first purchaced it months earlier. The time had come to sit down, and see what "Death On The Road" was all about, so I did....Honestly, although the editing / shifting of the camera can get dizzying at times {Rock In Rio}, this is a solid live effort from Maiden in my opinion. It took a few songs into the set before I could really start to appreciate this performance as a whole, but once songs like "Can I Play With Madness" / "The Trooper" kicked in, everything started clicking...What I really enjoyed about this performance was seeing that Maiden is still going strong. They still have a solid tightness after all these years, and although Bruce is losing his voice, he can still sound that siren when he wants to. Although I wouldn't call this the best Maiden performance I've ever seen, it's certainly much better than I was initially anticipating. I'm very happy that I finally gave this DVD a chance, and I'll certainly be watching it again....The "bonus features" DVD is great, and almost worth the price of this DVD alone in my opinion. You get tons of behind the scenes stuff from the making of "Dance Of Death", to interviews, touring, ect. This bonus DVD has it all, and I highly enjoyed watching it from start to finish....I can't go into anymore detail because that would ruin it. I'll just close by saying that Iron Maiden still has the goods. I wasn't completely sure of that until I watched this DVD. I have no more doubts. Solid 4 Stars....
summary: IRON MAIDEN : "Death On The Road - 2003 Tour"
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a review of the US DVD version that was released Feb 21.Disc Issues:- The stereo disc has an encoding problem at about 1:30 of Wildest Dreams. It looks like a huge green glitch all over the screen, and it lasts about five or six seconds. It is really noticeable and spoils the fun. There are also sound problems, where the bass would keep increasing and decreasing. I tried this in a cheap DVD player, and on my ibook laptop. I think the green glitch is inherent in the disc, and the sound problem is due to the low quality of the DVD player.- The surround disc was much much better: there was no glitch and the sound never did cut. However, when you choose to Play All in this disc, it keeps playing all songs in a row, but goes back to the song menu right before Brave New World starts. You have to select the song from the song menu again. I think it does it for Paschendale and Lord of the Flies as well. It's not really a big deal, but still, you'd prefer if you could just watch the whole thing without disruption. I tried this in both my DVD player and ibook, and I also think it's inherent to the disc.- Haven't watched the Bonus material yet, but it doesn't seem there are any issues, hearing from other people who've seen it.Editing:Some people are complaining that the editing is fast paced. I don't see any problem with it. Once you're into it, you won't even notice or care, just like Rock in Rio. The editing makes it feel like you're all over the concert: you're in the crowd, you're in front of Bruce, you're behind Nicko... all in the span of three or four seconds. It does alternate between color for the band, and black and white for the crowd. It also gives a bird-eye view of the whole stage, which is impressive to say the least.The Show:Sounds like those lucky Germans got to attend a sweet show. The stage, the costumes, the lights, the sound, everything is top notch. My only complaint is about the song selection: do we really need another Wrathchild or Trooper? Sure Maiden played six songs from the last album and one from Brave New World and X-Factor, but that's still not enough. We want to hear the other great songs that they don't play live usually. I mean, they could play the classics at the show, but they can get rid of them when mixing the live album to yield space to other forgotten gems. Hint: Man on the Edge, The Unbeliever, Ghost of the Navigator, Out of the Silent Planet, The Educated Fool, Maybe Lightning Strikes Twice just to pick from the latest albums!Conclusion:I am really glad Maiden are still recording and performing live. They certainly haven't lost any of their attitude or ambition. The technical difficulties are not their fault, so I'd give the disc 4 stars. With the difficulties, I think it deserves 3 stars._________________________________________________________________This is a review of the CD versionOther people have made the most important comment already: we, the fans, are tired of seeing all the classics in all the live albums. It doesn't hurt to play Total Eclipse, Out of the Silent Planet, Man on the Edge, Infinite Dreams and Powerslave from time to time.On the other hand we have six new songs from the new album, and all of them might become concert favorites apparently. Lord of the Flies is such a simple but effective song and it is probably the only breath of fresh air in the whole concert. I like how they left the concert unedited so you can hear the little screw-ups (vocals, Gers' guitar of course and the cymbal count before the beginning of a song...) The concert sounds both well produced and raw at the same time, and the mixing is great.I like how Maiden releases a lot of material in between albums to keep the hungry fans appeased. Hopefully we'll get a more interesting song list next time.

reviewText: Thanks, Mr. Steve Harris, for using the same headache-inducing edition technique used in the Rock In Rio DVD, one that does not permit any shot to last more than half-second, thus making the whole thing unwatchable and destroying an otherwise good product (good bonus DVD, good sound).It's unbeliavable how Harris did it again, how the manager, the record company, even his band-mates accepted this lousy edition job!

Title: N/A

reviewText: So many bad reviews, not because of bad picture or bad audio. No, picture and audio are both great. So many complaints because of how it was edited. Yes, Steve Harris did a lot of fast editing throughout to give the concert a fast-paced look. If you're epileptic, it can be bothersome. But don't let it discourage you from buying this or Rock In Rio (also edited by Harris). I've owned and viewed many concert dvds from Metallica, Megadeth, Anthrax, Judas Priest, Slayer, Testament, Overkill, Kreator, Cannibal Corpse, Napalm Death, Lamb Of God, Arch Enemy, Nevermore, Opeth, Dream Theater, Killing Joke, Nine Inch Nails, Ministry, Killswitch Engage, Exodus, Slipknot, Machine Head, etc. I've never worried about how editing was gonna make a concert look on dvd. There's only one thing I really worry about, and that's sound quality. I figure that a great live dvd depends on how great it sounds especially at a high volume. This can even determine, whether or not you'd want to buy a cd version of it if it's available. Back to the review, the editing is not as bad as it sounds according to others. It eventually slows down a little, enough for you to catch your breath. When it does, you can enjoy seeing members including Adrian Smith, Dave Murray, and Janick Gers doing their best as the three guitarists in the band. It would have been nice to have a few more classics in the tracklist, but with it already being 16 tracks long, I'll take it. Extras are great to watch, especially the Death On The Road documentary on the making of Dance Of Death and the tour behind it. I'd recommend this even to a new fan. If you're not convinced about buying it, there are youtube videos on the web.
summary: For what it is, a great product
Title: N/A

reviewText: Someone should get close to Steve Harris, look him in the eye and tell him: "Man, what are you doing?! You're the leader and owner of a legendary band, you're a hard working and highly talented musician and songwriter. Why are you destroying the recent DVD's with your ludicrous, terrible editing? Why are you doing this?!"The edition here reprises the blinding fast edition of the Rock in Rio DVD, but it's even faster! The whole thing is an exercise in determination to reach the end of the show. If you wanna watch a Dave Murray solo for more than one second, forget it. If you wann check Nicko through a complete drum roll, forget it. If you wanna be mesmerized by Steve's galloping fingers, you won't see it, pal. They are there somewhere, but Harris don't allow us to watch them.
summary: Insane edition = no joy at all!

reviewText: More serious than the already mentioned technical problems, it's the riculous edition of this thing. Nothing against using 342 cameras for shooting a show. But wanting to put a shot from every camera within one second the whole time is simply insane.I really would like to know what Dickinson, Smith, McBrain, Murray and even that parody of a guitar player Gers honestly think of the final result of Harris's edition... reviewText: Thanks 'Arry. Thanks for ruining another great concert that we all wanted to watch.One thing though: The packaging of this DVD is a gorgeous looking brownish-red box with 3 discs, 2 of them being THE EXACT SAME CONCERT, just one is Stereo and one is 5.1...The editing of this DVD gave me a headache, there are about what, 5000 cameras jumping all over the place. This is basically just Rock in Rio editing, just faster. The editing is so fast that you can hardly keep up with what is going on! First we see the crowd for 1 second... then we go to Bruce... Then half a second later is Steve then Nicko... WTF. I had to turn the TV off and use this as a live album halfway through. Yes, Rock in Rio had fast editing, but at least you didn't notice it after a while, and at least it didn't give you a headache.The extras are nice, but the concert? Just get the CD instead.

reviewerName: Rexomus "One man with courage makes a majority."
reviewText: I love Iron Maiden live. I own all there DVD shows and this by far is the most difficult to watch. As other reviewers have pointed out, the cuts are way to short. Each shot lasts about 1-2 seconds and can induce nasuesa to watch it. I own a production company and I can never imaging editing footage this way. If Iron Maiden gave me the master raw footage I would gladly re-edit this concert. With that said, the audio is good, and as the concert goes on it does become more viewable.The extras are great. The interviews and behind the scenes are well done.I can only recommend this DVD for Die Hard Iron Maiden Fans. The concert footage is tough to watch, the audio is great, and the extras are awesome.
summary: Tough to Watch Edit, Great Extras
Title: N/A

reviewText: Ok first of all, if you are posting a "...I'm rating the DVD quality not the content." Review, then all I have to say is "Please!!!" C'mon you were not duped by this because it was all over the Iron Maiden website and bulletin board. You knew there had to be issues because it was posted on Amazon as well. If you were fortunate to get a dvd before the recall, all you had to do in the bad parts is right when the song ends, hit the NEXT CHAPTER button on your remote and the concert continues on without a glitch. I don't find this annoying because I would much rather have this DVD than have to wait God only knows how long until the re-release happens, assuming it does happen.Now for the review of the DVD. This DVD is great!!! The behind the scenes with the band on the making of DOD in the studio and interviews with fans and road crew is exceptional! The concert is unbelievable! I've heard some complain about the quickness of shots. That didn't bother me because I felt this editing really captured the energy and essence of Iron Maiden. If you've never seen them live because you think they are too old and not like they were back in the day, this DVD will dispel that myth. I think the energy is just as good on LIVE AFTER DEATH (Powerslave tour) as it is here. The stage is just grand. The energy level is still there. If anyone has slowed down IT'S EDDIE! I'm used to seeing him run all over the stage in LIVE AFTER DEATH, but he just walks around here on DOD.So, if you can find this DVD, but you're afraid to buy it because of the error on tracks 6, 7, and 8, all you have to do is hit NEXT CHAPTER and you'll be fine. Sit back, relax, and UP THE IRONS!!!!!
summary: DESPITE THE FLAW, THIS DVD WAS WORTH THE WAIT!!!

reviewText: This is such a mess I don't even know where to start. You want a good representation of Iron Maiden live, I'm afraid this isn't it. The editing is poor and that's being too kind to say. There are major glitches in the replication of this that cause it to skip and jump and I even exchanged it once only to have the issues repeat in the same spots even on 3 seperate DVD players all of different brands in my home and office. I think this is even addressed on Iron Maiden's own site.In the rush for revenue it would appear quality takes a backseat these days as the latest Whitesnake live DVD also suffers the same manufacturing flaws and a statement on Whitesnake's site also addresses this. You would think when you drop $15-$23 on a DVD that it would work and more respect would be given to us buyers however my local Best Buy actually STOPPED CARRYING and SENT BACK both this Iron Maiden DVD and the Whitesnake because of the vast returns.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The 2007 release of Death On The Road is actually a third attempt after the first release attempt back at the beginning of 2006 had a plethora of disc problems ranging from audio mis-labels to manufacturing defects. The second attempt at releasing Death On The Road died in September 2006 for reasons unknown by me.So here it is. One year later and you can finally buy 2003's Death On The Road tour on DVD. Make no mistake...this DVD is NOT a performance associated with 2006's A Matter Of Life And Death tour; it is a performance from 2003's Dance of Death tour...clearly there could be some confusion on that matter.The Death On The Road DVD gives you:1. Wildest Dreams2. Wrathchild3. Can I Play with Madness4. The Trooper5. Dance of Death6. Rainmaker7. Brave New World8. Paschendale9. Lord of the Flies10. No More Lies11. Hallowed Be Thy Name12. Fear of the Dark13. Iron Maiden14. Journeyman15. The Number of the Beast16. Run to the Hills6 of the 16 are from the 2003 Dance of Death CD.Of the remaining 10 songs, 8 are on Rock in Rio. Leaving only Can I Play With Madness and Lord Of The Flies as new classic entries since the 2002 Rock in Rio release (which incidentally is on my Amazon Listmania list of The Best Hard Rock DVDs With High Quality A/V...click on my name above and visit my profile to check it out).Dance of Death was not as strong as Brave New World (The Brave New World tour is chronicled on the 2002 Rock in Rio DVD), and Dance was also not as strong as 2006's A Matter Of Life And Death. So if the Dance Of Death CD wasn't one of your favorites and you don't own the Rock in Rio DVD, I highly recommend going the route of 2002's Rio instead of 2003's Death On The Road.If you've got Rio already and have got to own everything Maiden, then this certainly is another opportunity. I'm counting on a future DVD release that perhaps switches out some of the classics (please guys, how about a nice high def update of say Flight of Icaris, 22 Acacia Avenue, Murders in the Rue Morgue, Where Eagles Dare and the like?).
summary: Ironing Out The Flaws. Good Show, Mates.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I love Iron Maiden but I only lasted 12 minutes with this DVD and had to turn it off.  It was making me physically uncomfortable due to the dreadfully fast scene changes.  I tried saying "one million" during each scene and hardly ever was able to finish saying it before the scene changed.  Only once did I ever make it to "two million", sometimes I only got to "one" before it changes, which is about a quarter of a second.  The band sounded great and I'll probably put it on again without turning on the TV and just use it as a live CD.  As a DVD it is truly awful.  I agree with G. Parnell, they should re-release this as a concert instead of one enormous ADD Music video.  Contrary to popular belief, the majority of us are NOT suffering from Attention Deficit Disorder.  I would have much preferred 1 camera as opposed to the 500 they used.  Iron Maiden doesn't need gimmicks to make their concerts interesting.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I had to buy this from an Amazon marketplace seller, but the process was quite easy (take note, all you frustrated fans who haven't got it yet) and I'm very happy I did.  Personally, I have not experienced ANY technical problems with the DVD.  The 5.1 disc IS the 5.1 disc in my set, and I had utterly no problems with the DVD leaving the concert and going back to the menu.  None.  And even if you do--so what?  Go back to the concert and get on with it!The extras disc was extremely enjoyable--in my opinion, the best extras disc the Maiden has had so far.  The documentary of the band in studio is fun, informative, and rewarding for the inquisitive fan.  The other features are also superb--one from the Maiden crew's perspective and one from the fans--and I feel very satisfied as a Maiden fan for having seen them, and I am likewise delighted that Maiden took time to do such a quality and careful job with all of the documentaries.As for the concert:  GREAT.  Yes, I totally agree, the setlist is frustratingly redundant in places.  There's not a Maiden fan out there who wouldn't enjoy hearing Alexander the Great, Powerslave, Futureal, Caught Somewhere in Time or even Holy Smoke over Yet Another Version of Number of the Beast, The Trooper, Run to the Hills, or Hallowed be Thy Name.  But, the fact is this...the performance was awesome on this DVD.  The songs from Dance of Death, including ones I didn't like that much on the album, were just fantastic in concert.  I loved Dance of Death and No More Lies even though I didn't like them much on the studio release, and Journeyman and Paschendale are worth the price of the DVD all by themselves.  The fans are clearly having a great time and very active throughout...sorry, I'm ranting.  It's just that, after all the hubub over the DVD's technical problems, I was expecting a train wreck.  Instead, I bought the second-best Maiden DVD ever (The Early Days is hard to beat).  It will be a sad shame if Steve Harris decides not to release it again in future.
summary: Technical problems OVERBLOWN--This DVD is Great Fun.

reviewText: I had to buy it on ebay because of the recall. Good DVD but could have been better. Mine does have the technical issues with going back to the main menu after three tracks, but I can handle that. The technical thing that bothers me and counts for half a star is the tinny treble sound and the cut out of the kick drum on and off throughout the show. The other half star deduction comes from the fast editing, especially in the beginning. At times a little fast editing can be a good thing and add to the song (as you you will see at times during the show), but they go way way,way,way, overboard at times!!! The conert itself is great and I am glad I got my hands on a copy.

Title: N/A

reviewText: This DVD is really not that bad. There still is the raw power of a Maiden concert coming through loud and clear. However the almost constanly changing camera angles can get old quite quick. This show had so much going on that there should have been less camera angle changes to allow the viewer to take it in. Additionally I would love Maiden to pull out some older numbers not the same "Wrathchild" etc. I mean a Maiden concert is not a concert without, "The Trooper" however, what happaend to "Remember Tomorrow", "Phamtom of the Opera", "Killers", "Where Eagles Dare"? Also this DVD shows the Janick Gers needs to calm down. His constant posing like Richie Blackmore and 360ing his guitar gets boring. It proves though that Murray and Smith really are the guitarists in the band, Murray especially. Gers just poses too much. He was fine in the "Rock In Rio" DVD, but here he mugs too much for the camera. Bottom line, this a good DVD concert, it goes to prove though that "Live After Death" is the best one so far from Maiden. Up the Irons !!!
Title: N/A
